instructions: Answer all questions on electrolysis and electroplating.

questions.question: What is electroplating?
options: Using electricity to coat an object with a metal
Splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen
questions.explanation: Electroplating uses electrolysis to deposit a thin layer of metal onto an object (e.g., silver-plating cutlery).

questions.question: In silver plating, the object to be plated is placed at the:
questions.explanation: The object to be plated is made the cathode, so positive metal ions (Ag⁺) are attracted and reduced onto it.

questions.question: In copper refining, impure copper is made the:
questions.explanation: Impure copper is the anode. It dissolves, Cu²⁺ ions go into solution, then pure copper deposits on the cathode.

questions.question: Why is direct current (DC) used in electroplating, not alternating current (AC)?
options: DC provides one-way flow to deposit metal steadily
questions.explanation: DC ensures metal ions always move toward the cathode and deposit. AC would reverse direction, preventing steady plating.

questions.question: Which is a common use of electroplating?
questions.explanation: Chromium plating is used for decoration and corrosion resistance on cars, taps, etc.

questions.question: In electroplating, the electrolyte contains:
questions.explanation: The electrolyte contains ions of the metal to be plated (e.g., Ag⁺ for silver plating).

questions.question: During electroplating, oxidation occurs at the:
questions.explanation: Anode = oxidation (loss of electrons). In silver plating, silver anode oxidizes: Ag → Ag⁺ + e⁻.

questions.question: What happens if the object to be plated is made the anode instead of cathode?
options: It dissolves instead of being coated
It gets plated with wrong metal
questions.explanation: If object is anode, it loses electrons and dissolves instead of gaining metal coating.

questions.question: Electroplating is used to:
questions.explanation: Main uses: corrosion resistance (e.g., zinc-plating iron) and decorative finish (e.g., gold-plating jewelry).

questions.question: For successful electroplating, the object must be:
options: Made of the same metal as the plating
questions.explanation: Surface must be clean so metal adheres well. Grease or dirt would cause poor plating.
